title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: The '''presidential transition of George W. Bush''' took place following the [[2000 United States presidential election]], after [[George W. Bush ]]was declared the victor of the [[2000 United States presidential election]] following the [[Bush v. Gore]] decision by the [[United States Supreme Court]] halted [[2000 United States presidential election recount in Florida]], making Bush the victor in that state, which delivered him the state's 25 [[United States Electoral College|electoral votes]], thus giving him a total of 271 electoral votes, one more than the 270 needed to win the presidency outright.

Due to the recount effort and litigation between Bush and his presidential opponent [[Al Gore]], Bush's presidential transition was abbreviated from the length it would have been had he been declared the victor closer to election night.
==Background==

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: The planning of the transition effort had begun substantially earlier than the official start of the transition.<ref name="presidentialtransition.org"/>

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: Bush proceeded quickly, after becoming president-elect to announce cabinet selections, announcing the majority of major cabinet designees by the end of December.<ref name="Vox1"/>

The transition experienced some controversy when Bush's selection for [[United States Secretary of Labor|Secretary of Labor]], [[Linda Chavez ]], withdrew her nomination on January 9 after the media reported that she had previously employed an [[undocumented immigrant]].<ref name="Vox1"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Fournier |first1=Ron |title=Chavez Withdraws As Labor Nominee |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/aponline/20010109/aponline172303_000.htm |website=www.washingtonpost.com |publisher=Washington Post |agency=The Associated Press |access-date=30 January 2021 |date=9 January 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Holmes |first1=Steven A. |last2=Greenhouse |first2=Steven |title=BUSH CHOICE FOR LABOR POST WITHDRAWS AND CITES FUROR OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT ISSUE (Published 2001) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/10/us/bush-choice-for-labor-post-withdraws-and-cites-furor-of-illegal-immigrant-issue.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=30 January 2021 |date=10 January 2001}}</ref>

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: On December 19, Bush met at [[Number One Observatory Circle]] with Gore, who was not just his defeated opponent, but also the outgoing vice president, <ref name="baer30jan"/> On December 20, Bush met in the [[White House]] with Clinton.<ref name="baer30jan">{{cite web |last1=Baer |first1=Susan |title=Clinton, Bush talk transition |url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-2000-12-20-0012200071-story.html |website=baltimoresun.com |publisher=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=30 January 2021 |date=20 December 2000}}</ref>

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: On December 19, Bush met in the [[White House]] with Clinton.<ref name="baer30jan">{{cite web |last1=Baer |first1=Susan |title=Clinton, Bush talk transition |url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-2000-12-20-0012200071-story.html |website=baltimoresun.com |publisher=The Baltimore Sun |access-date=30 January 2021 |date=20 December 2000}}</ref> That same day, Bush also met at [[Number One Observatory Circle]] with Gore, who was not just his defeated opponent, but also the outgoing vice president.<ref name="baer30jan"/>

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
Presidential transition of George W. Bush
deleted: The planning of the transition effort had begun substantially earlier than the official start of the transition.<ref name="presidentialtransition.org"/>

title: Presidential transition of George W. Bush
added: The [[9/11 Commission Report]] argued that the abbreviated transition had resultantly left many national security positions unfilled by the time of the [[September 11 attacks]], and that slow transitions such as that of Bush's can imperil the nation's national security.<ref>{{cite web |title=What the 9/11 Commission Found: Slow Confirmations Imperil U.S. National Security • Center for Presidential Transition |url=https://presidentialtransition.org/blog/what-the-9-11-commission-found/ |website=Center for Presidential Transition |access-date=30 January 2021 |date=16 December 2020}}</ref>
